commentBody:
"...know who's the ILLest ever, like the greatest story told..."

Out loud gasp at the tribute to MF DOOM, wowowow. RIP to a master.  Just remember ALLCAPS when you spell the man name! ‚ù§Ô∏è
I must be quaint, because I say "needn't" pretty frequently.
Wouldn't MMMCMXCIX be larger than MMMDCCCLXXXVIII ?

Caitlin,

XXXL is a rather large clothing size. XL is 40 (and also a not-as-large clothing size).
Can someone ammend 38A to be ALL CAPS please?

One more reminder about the GRIDDIES, first round voting ends tonight at 11:59pm EST. Ballot can be found here: https://form.jotform.com/253465756808167 Vote on as many as 5 in each category and hit submit. Then you're done -- until the next round. It's fun, it's easy, it shows appreciation for your game and for the constructors' ingenuity. Remember, they've constructed these puzzles to provide you with entertainment, some neural activity, and a sense of accomplishment. Let's reciprocate their generosity by honoring their puzzles!

The trivia strewn throughout feels so catered to me as a early genZ / late millenial, ive never solved a saturday so fast before!

its cool to see tchotchke and KNICKKNACK flipped because i swear tchotchke was the answer and knickknack was the clue a year ago.

now im gonna have GALBI for dinner thanks for that

Having never heard of GALBI, I couldn't fathom "LAP" being wrong in the SE corner and my time suffered as a result.

Oh well, a sign that I need more culture in my life. Excellent Saturday!
In Roman numerals, 40 is XL, not XXXL, hope that can be corrected in the column.
Weird.  I've always spelled Galbi with a K.  Kalbi.

Can someone explain to me how 8D is correct? Nearly every source on the interwebs says this answer is wholly incorrect. ‚Äú The lowest number you can write in Roman Numerals is number I (1). And the largest numeral is MMMCMXCIX (3999).‚Äù [1] ‚Äú According to the rules of addition and subtraction, this means that the biggest number we can form in Roman numerals is MMMCMXCIX, or 3,999.‚Äù [2] ‚Äú The largest number you can write in Roman numerals is 3,999 which is MMMCMXCIX. You can represent numbers larger than 3,999 in Roman numerals using an overline. An overline on a Roman numeral means you are multiplying that Roman numeral by 1,000.‚Äù [3] See: [1] https://www.romannumerals.org/blog/which-is-the-biggest-number-in-roman-numerals-6 [2] https://blog.prepscholar.com/roman-numerals-converter#google_vignette [3] https://www.calculatorsoup.com/calculators/conversions/roman-numeral-converter.php#:~:text=The%20largest%20number%20you%20can,that%20Roman%20numeral%20by%201%2C000.

This was tough for me.  After a pass through the acrosses I had exactly two entries totaling 7 letters, and one of them was wrong.  I was thinking of dropping an FBOMB.  Starting with CASE, however, I was able to work out the SE corner, helped by guessing STP, which gave me PITSTAINS, and from there onward and upward.  The limited  letter choices for 8D helped me get some crosses, which made up for my unfamiliarity with much of the general knowledge.  This one was definitely not ARTSYFARTSY, and neither was it FAUXNAIF.

Three cheers for ANTONIO Carlos Jobim, who brought his samba/jazz fusion to the swingin‚Äô sixties.  Getz/Gilberto sounds as fresh today as it did back in the day, and I know because The Girl From Ipanema, luminously sung by Astrid Gilberto, popped up on a playlist I was listening to earlier today.

I‚Äôll be interested to see how the commentariat reacts to the informality and somewhat low nature of some of the entries.  For the record it didn‚Äôt bother me.

Struggled with today. But it‚Äôs partly because my dad passed away yesterday. Oddly I didn‚Äôt automatically get Margarita=Daisy as I‚Äôm a PEO and one of our symbols is the Marguerite Daisy. Loll. Loved the cross of artsy fartsy big Catan player. And a teacher who‚Äôs 12-13 years old kids regularly drop FBOMBS

DELINT:  activity that follows yesterday‚Äôs HERDING CATS.

I speak from experience.

Pretty fun and fast.  While I'd like to think I'm getting better, I also think this was on the easy side.  I was ignorant of the rules for the spanner (I confess I expected all Ms) but it was nearly a gimme anyway as the numeral set is so small.

Interesting that there was an extra F bomb in the puzzle.  I didn't think the grey lady acknowledged bodily functions...

Weird one today, felt really difficult while I was doing it but ended up being fast.

It was neat to learn that (standard) roman numerals have a limit. I was confused by the clue because I had assumed you could just keep stacking on as many Ms as you want.

The clue for PESOS seemed iffy to me. Most of the taquerias I've been to use dollars.
Odd choice to make every single answer DOODYHEAD, but with 365 of these to publish a year I guess they can‚Äôt all be winners.

On the whole enjoyed this‚Ä¶ a few toughies‚Ä¶ 
Tinder bio was a good one and the Roman numerals was fun, eliminating across clues that didn‚Äôt contain M, C, D, V or I... 
But lawyer‚Äôs assignment-CASE??? That was very Monday/Tuesday!

I raced through this puzzle and ended up with some fly-specking left to do at the end. (Somehow I knew TISDERPIO was the problem!) It‚Äôs been a great weekend for fun and fresh themeless puzzles. A few years ago Thursdays were my favorites, but I‚Äôm really starting to enjoy Fridays and Saturdays! üòä

What‚Äôs fresh about this puzzle?  Well, Ladies and GERMS, we have:

SIDEWALKS running
PHD level cluing for STP
A humongus  Roman numeral
MIXINS / MKAY 
An ARTSY FARTSY FAUX NA√èF
PIT STAINS

And top it all off with the FBOMB‚Ä¶

Yowzah!
Wow, this one took me longer than usual to get through...words that I thought would work, didn't. Frustrating. Not the usual clues and answers.

"Oh, I know what that herb is called...oh, it's right on the tip of my tongue..."
"Oooh, I'm sorry, you're out of thyme."

(Me, losing on "The Spice Is Right")
This was fun. A nice challenge almost totally devoid of crosswordese.

I am finally *starting* to get a bit my swagger back after having been blue-starred Wednesday and Thursday of last week.

I really liked [Dough at a taquer√≠a].   

And 8D should be a crossword hall of fame, for my money.

33A was a great tribute, and it's nearly his day.

I used to sing Tennessee Ernie Ford's song "Sixteen tons" as I'd drag my behind to work, before I retired.  

As a software developer.  

It would remind me of what a great life I had, because I loaded a lot less than sixteen tons, and though I was a day older, I was not deeper in debt.  What a great song.

This one started slowly, then I made a few correct guesses (ANTONIO, BOND for the end of 12D and KICKS for the end of 13D, for instance), and suddenly found things were going quickly. Despite never having heard of the rapper, board game, or the island's nickname, and never having read or watched Handmaiden's Tale, I was suddenly finished in about 1/3 of my average time. I enjoyed a lot of the clever clueing, and enjoyed the solve - even though it seemed to be over too soon 

But I'm still lost on 36D. Can somebody please explain to me why SAPS are good marks? 
[ Doh! 
Never mind. The answer came to me as I finished typing the question - talk about a FACEPALM moment!! ]

What a challenging, delightful experience this was.  Sometimes you want to track down the constructor and let 'em have it, but this was like learning to play a new piece of music on an instrument.  False starts, difficult runs, but it all came together when you found the right slant and the right set of words to fill it.

Thank you, Adam.  This whole week has been a stream of stressful appointments, worrisome conclusions, disappointing outcomes, and that was just the personal stuff, happening while the whole country is blowing up, a city at a time.  The puzzle was a small escape, absorbing, entertaining, and fun.
Margarita is a Spanish word, having a meaning that can be translated into English. The phrasing of the 2A clue is incorrect.

Anybody want to know how to do multiplication in Roman numerals?

It's something I learned how to do to divert myself last November.

I think division is essentially impossible.

I was surprised when I finished and saw that my completion time was so much lower than my Saturday average, because it felt like a tricky one! After all, I had battled to get going initially, and had had to google a couple of things. Still, in the end, it proved to be a very enjoyable puzzle and just right for a Saturday. 

I was unsure about NEEDN‚ÄôT when I first filled it in, because it doesn‚Äôt seem all that quaint to me (I use it all the time), but then remembered that my old English teacher had referred to my writing style as quaint (complimentarily, I think) when I‚Äôd just written the way I speak!

This ultimately proved unsolvable without aid for me. With some effort I completed the top half of the grid on my own, but I knew too little to handle the bottom half, and I really just wasn't vibing with the clues in general. I personally found the gimmick with the Roman numeral annoying rather than anything else (even though I'm quite good with Roman numerals in general).

It wasn't an objectively bad puzzle, of course, but it brought me little joy.

How is BRANDNAME the answer to "Reputable, in a way". Is BRAND NAME used as an adjective here? I'm confused.

The top half was pretty much a breeze for me, especially since I guessed right on FBOMB and though I had fun piecing out the Roman numeral, but it was pretty easy to do. I thought this would be a pretty unremarkable puzzle but then hit some roadblocks and really fun clues/entries in the lower half: ARTSY FARTSY? Ladies and GERMS? FAUXNAIF? PITSTAINS? TINDERBIO? (My first thought was DRIVERSID). Not complaining, I was delighted and this ended up being a worthy Saturday. A few random thoughts: If I were a company making generics I‚Äôd be pretty upset at 15 across‚Äîthey are usually no less reputable than the BRANDNAMES, even in the medication category. Interesting the echoes of yesterday‚Äôs puzzle: FAUX, a deodorant clue, and for me FACEPALMS which arguably could be types of FACEPLANTS in my mistaken entry. Finally if anyone has any doubts about the legitimacy of MKAY they need to watch an episode of ‚ÄúSouth Park‚Äù with Mr. Mackie: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=KeprIqxrDQo

As a chemist, I should point out the brilliance of 12D [In which opposites attract].

However, I discovered that MAGNETISM has the same number of letters as IONICBOND, and yet share not a single consonant, and none of the letter positions have the same letters.

Sheesh.

You'd think the man would sell Mum at that dang company store.

So, even though you owed your soul, no unsightly pit disasters!

How 'bout less B.O.  already, constructors.

P.S. 
A possible change of vocation that took the air out my solving tires for a hotsec:

C O A L M I N E R
C A B D R I V E R

It ain't like I never hollered that song while digging mighty fine holes in the backyard of beyond.
Not fun for me. Too difficult. Too obscure.
Whats the term for non-artificial unsophistication? Just feeling that midway in, because alas I can‚Äôt even, who does(?), forget subtractive notation?
now THAT was a saturday!
Just remember ALL CAPS when you spell the man name!
What a wonderful puzzle! Thanks so much Adam!

I was a bit surprised as I got through this well under my average time. Not that it was particularly easy, but there were several things that I knew or could essay a reasonable guess, and they turned out to be correct.

Knew CATAN, Jobim, tchotchkes, had heard ARTSY‚Ä¶, and owned cameras with moderately-sized sensors. A lot of the rest was familiar and filled in easily once crosses were in place. FAUX NAIF was unfamiliar, but obvious in translation (of what little French I know).

A fun Saturday for me; thanks Adam
Rare ego boost. Whenever I breeze through one, everyone else and their 10 year old son does too.  A couple people had some issues‚Ä¶I will take that as progress .
I don't know if I'm seriously missing something, but I don't understand "saps" being connected to "good marks". The internet has also helped me none.

Done in by the Southeast corner. Just could not see TINDER BIO or SIDEWALKS. Knowing the name of the Korean dish might have helped. No matter, been a while since I found a Saturday so challenging,  yet mostly solvable.  
Nice to see MLK in the center on his weekend.
Today, I discovered that across the pond, needn‚Äôt is considered quaint, and from the Mini that Mollusc is spelt with a k.

Called out by the crossword! Guilty as charged, my TINDERBIO rounds up an inch. On a messy hair day it adds a little padding which has to count for something! I know my boosted ego from getting this one 98% completed puffs me up some too - stumped only by whatever the heck an egg cream alternative is.
XCLLent puzzle!
Great puzzle

That was WAY too easy for a Saturday.  Not.  I sweated this one and thus the completion was especially gratifying.  My first jaunt through the grid I got very few words but eventually the puzzle revealed itself as it always does eventually.  This is my favorite kind of Saturday puzzle--when you think ok I can't do this on my own and then see that I can, based on excellent, fair, natick-free construction.  Thank you Adam Aaronson.
The "dough at a taqueria" clue was unnecessary. I know it is clever wordplay and all, but sometimes you got to read the room a bit.

Found this a weird one from a difficulty point of view. I had to concede defeat early on and a Check Puzzle erased half my answers. I had close to nothing, but one short reveal word in each quadrant pretty much let me run through all of each area. It was fast when you were motoring, but dead stop when you were stuck.

Even while going through it I had no idea what to do with the Roman numerals, kudos to anyone who knew it was even possible to figure out what the max number could be. I wasn‚Äôt even able to read the number when it was all there.

Very good Saturday. 

Like others I don‚Äôt find NEEDNT quaint but that‚Äôs such a trivial comment that it can only belong here. MKAY and MIXINS are new to me but the M was the only reasonable choice. 

The constructor‚Äôs notes are a delightful insight. 

The commentariat has a lovely chain after @Andrzej ‚Äôs comment.

This did not start off full of hope, oof. Luckily, I read the clue for the Roman numeral relatively early on, worked it backwards from the I to the M and that gave me the spine of the grid, from which I then built on. As I did, thinking about the clues (very, very few of which were gimmes), filling in the entries bit by bit, I was very aware of how extremely well this puzzle had been thought out. I finished pretty quickly given its level of difficulty (just barely sliding in with single digits, if I may brag for a moment), despite the Saturday-like vagueness of the clues and lots of unknowns, but that‚Äôs just such a testament to the skill of the constructor. This was all about logic and free-associating. The absolutely best kind of puzzle. 

Who is this masked crusader, I asked myself when I finished. 

Ah. Adam Aronson. Well, no wonder then. Hats off, Adam. The work of a master. 

One nit. A borderline political one. MLK is clued as a string of letters. Okay, fine, I won‚Äôt quibble with the slightly flippant clue because it‚Äôs hard to clue him without immediately giving away the answer since he‚Äôs such an iconic figure. But then we have Lenin with the anodyne clue of an ‚Äúadvocate‚Äù for ‚Äúpolitical mobilization.‚Äù The man was directly responsible for hundreds of thousands of deaths (millions in some estimates). He was the author of the Red Terror, Cheka, camps, unspeakable brutality. 

C‚Äômon, editors. You don‚Äôt pull punches when you clue Idi Amin. A nice, positive Lenin, though?
First thought was that the zinc compound must be in a sunscreen. I do not advise using STP for this purpose.
I don‚Äôt know how many times I‚Äôve been asked ‚Äúwhat is the longest number you can write in standard Roman numerals?‚Äù, but it‚Äôs not that many.
It was hard work and then suddenly it was done and quicker than my usual Saturday time? I don‚Äôt understand but I loved it. Dough at a taqueria was my fave.
As an artist/designer, I honestly loved that Artsy Fartsy was included. Good Saturday puzzle.
I was Roman around this puzzle for the longest time.
LOVE LOVE Roman numerals!

This poetic misadventure has been twice emu‚Äôd since last night.  Maybe it‚Äôll appear later but I‚Äôve changed DOOM‚Äôs first name to EMF in case his moniker is the culprit.  If not, then this will be emu‚Äôd too and I‚Äôll accept that the emus simply have good taste.


I‚Äôve Got More Soul Than a Sock With a Hole*

On ARTSY FARTSY SIDEWALKS
Cats playin‚Äô CATAN and RISK
SAPS tryin‚Äô out SPINKICKS
FAUX NAIFS sellin‚Äô KNICKNACKS
FBI handin‚Äô out kickbacks
Madvillain rhymin‚Äô over SAX tracks
Bob Dylan tryin‚Äô on a WET RAINCOAT
Paid 3,888 YEN for a MALTED float
But hey man, it‚Äôs MLK DAY,
Call me a KOOK, that‚Äôs MKAY,
Stop ASKIN‚Äô if we OUT OF TIME
Just put a BRAND NAME on that ILL rhyme.

* EMF DOOM (aka Madvillain) lyric

Is IONIC BOND James's clingy brother?





Et tu, emu.

I'm  OK with Roman numerals, but there was no way I was going to get 8 D without some crosses.  I could at least fill in the first and last 4 with a good degree of certainty, so that got me off to a decent start.  

This was one of those puzzles that looked difficult but solved fairly quickly.  Things I don't know anything about filled in with just a couple of crosses.  IONIC BOND?  Not in my wheelhouse, but obvious once I had NIC, it popped into my head.  Same with MEGAPIXELS and FAUX NAIF.  

Some fun cluing, like [Dough at a taqueria] for PESOS, [Where someone's height may be stretched] for TINDER BIO and [Cabin choice] for AISLE SEAT.
Why are bracket contents TEAMS? I was thinking of sets, in math, or income levels‚Äî?

Fun puzzle today: just about the midpoint between my best and average.

Had DATINGAPP before TINDERBIO and UMBRELLA before RAINCOAT, but on the other hand I got the euphemism FBOMB without any help from the crosses, so that's a real feather in my cap, I guess. I was almost deterred from SAX by the letter juxtaposition in the Down answer that it would have necessitated, but I had no other ideas so it stayed.

Oh, and one last thing. "Also spelled CATAN"? I've never seen it any other way, have you?

Easier than yesterday's for me, since the long Roman numeral was a 15-box gift.

What struck me most about this puzzle was the number of times IN appeared in the grid. I counted 11. I wonder if this is more than usual, or if the IN pairs were simply highlighted for me by MIXINS, LAIDIN, ASKIN and, of course, LENIN. ;-)

For "Worker who's the subject of the song "Sixteen Tons", I was dredging my brain for a specific name, not the generic COALMINER. And the opposite for "Advocate for the political mobilization of the proletariat", where I was struggling to find a generic term, not LENIN.

I also fell for "Dough at a taquer√≠a", until GAP made PESOS clear.

For Roman numerals, with I, X, and C you are limited to three because of the option to subtract, but since that's not an option for M, did they really have a rule that you can't write MMMM? Is MMMM good?

Hey, this puzzle had pop, felt alive.  

Not only because of the four X‚Äôs and eight K‚Äôs, but also the 12 NYT debut answers.  Debut answers aren‚Äôt always premier ‚Äì and some of today‚Äôs aren‚Äôt, IMO ‚Äì but they always give the solver an answer and clue never seen before, and double-digit debuts defy same-old same-old.

It is also junk free, but I say that in passing, because all of AA‚Äôs grids are.  

That spanning Roman numeral?  I sheeshed when it looked like every square of it would depend on crosses.  But then I started liking it more and more because the seven Roman numeral letters helped me check the crossing answers.  

Also, that Roman numeral is a rare-in-crosswords 15-letter semordnilap (just kidding).

The 15 longs kept things fun and interesting, not to mention lovely shorts as well ‚Äì BASK, KOOK, MKAY, and FOIST.  I liked BRAND NAME sharing the box with GAP and STP.

Enough bite to happify my brain, enough pop to heighten my mood.  Bravo, Aaron, and thank you!

Just...stop.

Stop it.

KNICKKNACK?
ARTSYFARTSY?
PITSTAINS?
FBOMB?


FACEPALM.

Mr Aronson? Bravo.

friend requests or emails from 
someone named, I don't know,
let's say like-
CeeCee, or
CC, 
or something like that,
she (or he...I don't know)
probably wants to beg you to collaborate on a puzzle
sh-...*they* may *hypothetically* be working on,
and may (hypothetically) 
grovel. 

Hypothetically.

fake palms : face palms :: face plants : fake plants

Crossword puzzle synchronicities are so fun

Tough cookie to crumble but enjoyable. 

Can someone explain how SAPS is good marks?

I always thought that jump kicks were mostly flashy. Once you're airborne, your path is fixed by the laws of physics, and your opponent can take advantage of that.

I spoke to a black belt once who described the entirety of a bout which resulted in him winning a tournament in a single sentence. The description was: "He leapt into the air...so I hit him."
just remember ALL CAPS when you spell the man name
After Friday's imbroglio, this was just right. Difficult but not on the crazy difficult spectrum.

Has anyone ever called Thelonious Monk "quaint"? Well, I woulndn't, and you NEEDN'T. Today's ear worm: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zBY7lBkyCs8 Happy to have this song in my head this chilly Saturday.

Another hard one for me. I ended up revealing or looking up quite a lot, it might help in future crosswords.

Some complete unknowns - MIXINS, ILL, (and the rapper), GERMS, ANTONIO, STP, LAID IN, the BOND and the KICKS, the PIXELS, GALBI, anything to do with sororities. 

I would say debobble, not DELINT! I've just bought an electric one, it's magic. The ARTSY clue - a familiar expression but without the 'S'. 

Amazingly, I know about egg creams, from my time in NYC in 1974-75.
The ODDs of a Puzzlemucker poem and a cup of smug with Audrey LM on the same day are about MMMDCCCLXXXVIII to I. Nice to see you both.
Any puzzle that mentions MF DOOM is okay by me. His rhymes were the ILLest.

My brain is hurting. So tempted to look at answer key but will heat up my tea and keep on. 
Germs made me laugh and remember.

My life was simplified once I realized LONGEST NEEDNT mean the LARGEST.  
I also wanted  TWASNT for the contraction.
I guess that the demands of the 8D Themer created the need for simpler fill.

When our mother said NEEDNT, it came out sounding like NEEN, as in "You NEEN to make faces when you see canned spinach!" ...which wasn't even the truth.

The Korean language has a G in it?  GALBI sounds like a Roman Caesar

Whew. Tough for me, especially because of 8d. There was no way I was going to figure that out just from the clues so it was all from the crosses. No big deal - just made for a long workout. Answer history search today was inspired by 33a, since we're just two days away from his day, which is a big deal down here. Anyway - a Monday from January 20 (!) 1986 by Joy L. Wouk. Theme answers in that one: CORETTASCOTT IHAVEADREAM CIVILRIGHTS MARTINLUTHER Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=1/20/1986&g=52&d=A ....
I adored this puzzle. Don't really know why. The unguessable number down the center just made it really zen for me.
Tough, but certainly doable and fun...especially when the 'pretentiously creative' answers revealed themselves...hahaha.

A pleasant Saturday puzzle.  I tend to like them on the simpler side, so it may not be everyone's cup of tea.

I was quite impressed with the Roman Numeral grid spanner.

Was anyone else naticked with LAP for 43A and wasn't up on semi-obscure Korean barbecued ribs?

I really enjoyed this grid and the constructor notes -- thank you, Adam! I have long admired Newberry Medal award-winning author LOIS LOWRY (Number the Stars, The Giver, and so many more gorgeous stories) and was so pleased to see her featured in today's puzzle.

Happy Saturday, everyone!
GALBI, FOIST, FAUXNAIF gave me a run for my money today! Lovely Saturday puzzle!
Brilliant! The seemingly impossible 8 Down actually provided much-needed clues for the Acrosses.

Ugh, I have never, ever, ever seen Galbi. I've always seen Kalbi even though most Koreans pronounce the K very soft.  

I enjoyed the puzzle though.  This is not a complaint!

I found this a somewhat hard but satisfying puzzle (only 30 sec under average time which has been heavily weighted high by my early Saturdays and some big outliers). It was an extremely helpful to have the big long down restricted to a limited number of letters even if I wasn't 100% certain of where some of them would fall.

I do have a question about TINDERBIO, though. I didn't get that first swing through because of the clue ending in a question mark. I thought that implied that it's not the obvious answer to the clue, some punny meaning, or such. But the obvious place to me that people stretch their heights is dating apps? Is there a more common answer I'm missing? Are people out in the world lying on torture racks to try to be taller or something?

This was delightful. Some came easily. Some were difficult. A great mix. When I saw 8 down I thought I was doomed but I got most of it with the crosses. Lots of good stuff! Thanks, Adam! A good Saturday to y‚Äôall!

Good morning, Ladies and Germs! Would it be disingenious to say one is faux naif? Was confused by saps being good marks -- on a tree, perhaps? But then I saw the comment below explaining that a sap is a good mark for a con.
7D - Said no basketball fan or announcer ever
FBOMB, ARTSY FARTSY, PITSTAIN.  Anyone else find today's puzzle just a little on the crude side?

[Billy the blade of grass warn't knee-high to a grasshopper as a sprout, but the nurturing spring rains helped him grow to the dizzying heights of a grasshopper leaping mightily as if to reach a book of Aesop's fables on the top shelf-the books having been arranged alphabetically. The summer came in dryer than a Milton Berle set and lo, Billy withers. In time Billy and Billy's buds were gathered in a tuft that helped spark a toasty campfire, around which children ate s'mores and told ghost stories.]









TINDER BIO
An absolute grind to the end!
VERY VERY Difficult. Way above my pay grade. Broke my no-lookups streak. I'm a good to very good solver, but this one put me to shame.
Oops, 39D

Perfect crunchy Saturday with lots of X‚Äôs & K‚Äôs! 

FauxNaif & ArtsyFartsy were my favorites & I will work into casual conversation today.

Still wondering - why are SAPS good marks?

Astounding.  Usually I complain that a themed puzzle forces too many non-words and 'Naticks', but this one pulls it off.  To learn the longest Roman numeral, all the while beholding all those Xs and Cs and letters in a row fitting with (mostly) actual words.. maybe the most amazing puzzle I've ever seen.
Attempted a start last night, plugged in FACEPALMS and then quit while I was ahead.  Smooth and fun morning solve with an interesting numerology lesson.  Gratias multas.

It was a definite surprise ‚Äî though a welcome one ‚Äî to see an MF DOOM clue in the Grey Lady (and a relatively obscure bar IMHO, even if it was itself an homage to "Love You Down"). Disappointed that the ALL CAPS didn't make it past the editors, but I certainly understand not wanting to cross them. Perhaps "ALLCAPS" could make a cute clue in the future, as in "How one is instructed to spell MF Doom's handle."
Bravo! Surprised myself finishing under my average time, then wished I there was more puzzle. Thanks!

Confidently plopped down DATING APP for 53A which made uncovering the true answer all the more satisfying.

Alternatively, one‚Äôs height could be stretched on one of those Inquisition era devices but I‚Äôm more than glad that that route was not taken.

Maybe next time Procrustes will have his chance to shine‚Ä¶

Anyways, kudos to Mr Aaronson on a crisp puzzle with sparkling fill!
NEEDN'T is "quaint"? Oof. Tell me I'm old without telling me I'm old.

Just another lazy Saturday morning for me -- but, then again, I'm retired, and every day is Saturday.  So I was just sitting around, sucking on coca leaves, listening to my MF Doom albums (as usual) and thinking what a fine lyricist he is. Yes and no. (How tedious that this is so often the answer.) The active ingredient is legally required to be identical but there is other stuff ('accipients') that can legally vary. The egg cream is a classic soda fountain drink characterized by its dense white foam head, balanced sweetness, and refreshing fizz. In its truest form, the recipe features just three ingredients:
‚Ä¢ Chocolate syrup
‚Ä¢ Very cold milk
‚Ä¢ Highly carbonated seltzer
Despite its misleading moniker, it contains no eggs, no cream‚Äîjust a simple, almost magical chemistry between these basic ingredients.

A malted (or malted milkshake) serves as a classic alternative to an egg cream primarily because both are iconic, nostalgic soda fountain beverages with similar, rich, and often chocolaty flavor profiles, despite having different textures and ingredients. A malted is frequently chosen as a richer, thicker alternative, whereas an egg cream is a lighter, fizzy, and more refreshing choice.

I taught Latin for a few months at an all-girls Catholic high school. The English teacher was on maternity leave and I covered her English classes for 3 months but also her Latin classes. I had taken some Latin at Northwestern, before starting my Masters in English, so they thought I could fake my way through the Latin classes. I stayed up late every night going through my Latin grammar books to try and pass myself off as competent. It was stressful but I loved the Latin classes because those young women really wanted to be there, while most in my English classes had little to no interest in reading or discussing The Odyssey. 
I decided teaching high school was not for me. I later went back to grad school for another MA in Linguistics and loved it. I ended up teaching ESL to adults at a community college, best job I ever had.
